is the fifth largest of the main
an Islands.  The largest town on the island is Kaunakakai, which is one of two small ports on the island.

value: Mouth of Hālawa Valley on the eastern end of the Island of Moloka'i

, which is its physical location. The airport has two runways that accommodate commuter/air taxi and general aviation activities, as well as some military flights.  +1 808 567-9660.

Molokaʻi. Travel time is approximately 90 minutes. $67.60 one-way for adults, $33.80 for children, infants (3 and under) free.  Two carry on items per person; freight charges for anything in excess of two items.
Many of the sights and beaches are spread out across the island so a car or tourbus is the best way to get around.

value: content=Car rental rates and information. Discount rental rates for fully equipped current model cars on Molokaʻi. MKK Airport location.

For shorter distances, mules and horses are another option.

value: content=Striking views of the north shore of Molokai, the world's highest sea cliffs reaching 1,700 feet - and the Kalaupapa Peninsula. Informational plaques about Father Damien and the Kalaupapa Leper Colony.

content= Site of forced isolation from 1866 until 1969 of people from Hawai'i afflicted with Hansen's disease (leprosy), a disease shrouded in fear and ignorance for centuries.  Public access to this community is very limited because of regulations safeguarding privacy. State law requires all individuals to secure a permit to enter. You can hike, ride, or fly down to Kalaupapa.

offers fly-in tours from Oahu and Molokai, hiking permits and guided mule tours. 
:*
offers one-day tours from Oahu with Waikiki hotel pickup and round-trip flight

value: content= Reservations suggested for hikes, mule treks and tours.
directions=Pala'au State Park at the end of Highway 470

content= Located 200 yards from the Kalaupapa Lookout, at the base of Nananhoa Hill, is the six-foot high Phallic Rock. Throughout the ages, barren women would bring offerings and spend the night at this site in hopes of conceiving a child. Women still come here with their offerings and pray for fertility. A beautiful ironwood forest surrounds this area, coating the ground with its long needles and creating a mood of peace and spirtuality.
, Highway 460 about 1.5 miles (2.4 km) east of Kaunakakai.
directions=Follow Kaluakoi road to Papohaku Beach Park

content= Hawaii's longest white sand beach. Three miles long and you'll rarely see anyone else on it. Very dangerous rip currents and shore breaks. DO NOT SWIM HERE unless the ocean is absolutely, positively, flat & calm.  Beach Park has restrooms, showers and fresh water.
name=Kapukahehu Beach - aka Dixie Maru Beach
directions=Kaluakoi Road to Pohakuloa Road until it ends in a cul de sac
content= Cresent beach in a small cove. Favorite of residents & visitors. Safe swimming almost always. However, large winter surf can create dangerous shore break. No facilities.
directions=Kaluakoi Road to Kepuhi Place, then Ke Nani Kai condos drive
content=  A very nice beach that is a favorite surfing spot. Dangerous when winter surf is up, usually safe for swimming in the summer. No facilities.
name=Pohaku Mauliuli Beach - aka Make Horse
directions=Kaluakoi Road to Kakaako Road to Lio Place
content= A great spot for a summer get-away. Dangerous when winter surf is up, usually safe for swimming in the summer. The Keawe trees near the beach provide comfortable shade.  No facilities.
directions=Maunaloa Highway (460) to Maunaloa town. Take the first right, drive 7 miles

content= Several beaches on the west side of the harbor; Hale o Lono Beach, Kanalukaha Beach, Kapukuwahine Beach, Kahalepohaku Beach and there is Halena Beach on the east side. Dangerous when winter surf is up, usually safe for swimming in the summer unless there is a south swell running. Exercise caution year-round. No facilities.
directions=Follow Kam V Highway to about mile 3.3
content=  Long, flat beach, nice sand. Safe wading anytime. Great for small children. Restrooms and showers, Pavilion and fresh water.
directions=Kam V Highway east to mile 5.4
content= A roadside picnic area with narrow beach. Safe wading year round.  No facilities.
directions=Kam V Highway east to mile 10.1
content= Nice beach at the old Kamalo Wharf site. Usually safe for wading/swimming year round.  No facilities.
directions=Kam V Highway to about mile 15.8
content= Short, flat beach about 50 yards long. Safe swimming when ocean is calm or no south swell.  No facilities.
directions=Kam V Highway east to mile 20
content= Molokai's favorite snorkel spot, a lovely point of golden sand and calm water.  No facilities.
directions=Kam V Highway past mile 21. Sandy Beach is right on the road.
content= Small, white sand, cresent shaped beach. No facilities.
directions=Kam V Highway to the pavement's very end in Halawa Valley
content= A fairly long curved beach with nice sand. Restrooms in the Halawa Park.

content= A historic 9-hole plantation-style course on the lush hillsides of cool and tranquil Kalae in central Molokai. Uneven fairways, small greens, towering eucalyptus trees, and dramatic elevation changes make Ironwood Hills as challenging as it is beautiful.
Activities including scuba, reef snorkel, ocean kayak, whale watch and sport fishing adventures.

Moaula and Hipuapua Falls are located on private land above Halawa Valley. The path is not well marked and you will need a guide to obtain permission and lead you to the falls. Both falls can, however, be viewed from multiple lookouts along Highway 450. Moaula Falls is a double-tiered fall which drops a total of 250 feet into a pool at the bottom. Native flowers, mangoes, ginger, ha'u trees and ancient taro patches line the hike.

value: content= Hike to Halawa Valley's spectacular 250 foot Moaula Falls with cultural guides and learn the ancient history of the many archaeological sites you see along the way.

content= Guided tours through trails once used by ancient Hawaiians. Spectacular views of waterfalls, rivers, and an ecological arboretum. Trails for advanced, moderate or light hikers and backpackers.
content=There is free coffee, maps, information & WIFI readibly available.
content=Learn how macadamia nuts are grown and crack your own.
Country cafe - full menu, nightly dinner specials.
directions=Makai side of Hwy 450 at Mohala Street

Molokaʻi vacation rental options include the three west end condominium choices, Paniolo Hale, Ke Nani Kai and Kaluakoi Villas. Two other condo options are Molokai Shores
in central Molokaʻi and Wavecrest Resort on the island's east end. There are a few bed & breakfast and other unique choices.

value: content=Features open-air, oceanfront bungalows located on Kamiloloa Beach. Pet friendly suites are available. Amenities offered include a swimming pool, an oceanfront restaurant and on-site spa facilities.
content=Stay at Molokai's popular Kaluakoi Villas located on the west end of the island. Featuring great amenities including the Kaluakoi Golf Course.
Private beach houses and bungalows are available on the west end and along the fringing reef of Molokaʻi east end.

There are two state parks on this island which allow camping. Both have showers and bathrooms.
